projects.title: Microcontroller based DC motor speed control
projects.description: Implemented a closed loop feedback based speed control software algorithm in PIC Microcontroller for a 2.5 Watt DC Motor using Pulse Width Modulated (<l>PWM</l>) switching of the supplied DC power to the motor. The speed of the motor is sensed by using a Photo Interrupter sensor setup across the spindle of the motor. The <l>PWM</l> signal is generated from the Microcontrollers <l>PWM</l> module according to the algorithm written. The <l>PWM</l> signal is connected to the driver circuit which controls the power supply to the DC motor. The width of the generated <l>PWM</l> switching signal to the motor’s DC power supply is continuously adjusted by the control software based on the calculated difference in the sensed speed and the user desired speed. The user desired speed is sensed through a potentiometer which is adjustable by the user.

projects.title: Feature extraction and classification of ECG signals using Discrete Wavelet Transform & Artificial Neural Networks
projects.description: Implemented an algorithm in <l>MATLAB</l> for classification of Electrocardiogram (ECG) Signals. Inbuilt <l>MATLAB</l> functions were used to implement the Artificial Neural Network (ANN). The ECG Database from Physionet is used for ANN training and testing of the program. The Statistical parameters (Standard deviation, Mean, variance, etc..) of the Wavelet coefficients of the ECG signal are taken as the features for detecting the abnormality.

projects.title: Wireless Embedded System for Powerline Monitoring
projects.description:
Implemented a WiFi and IEEE 802.15.4 based wireless embedded system (Hardware & Software) for continuous monitoring of the electric parameters of an Electric Power Transmission Line. The system consisted the following sub-modules:
  1. A pair of Hall effect based transducers for sensing the voltage & current.
  2. Microcontroller with built in ADC modules for signal processing.
  3. WiFi & ZigBee based Wireless transceiver modules for wireless communication.
  4. Personal Computer for Visualization.
The software developed using C# & .Net using Visual Studio visulaized the following in real-time:
  • Time domain representation of voltage & current waveforms.
  • Frequency domain representation of voltage or current signal.
  • Phasor diagram showing phase difference between voltage & current waveforms.
  • RMS values of voltage and current.

projects.title: Simulation of 4-Bit Microprocessor
projects.description:
Simulated a 4-bit Microprocessor in ModelSim HDL Simulator using Verilog Hardware Description Language along with a custom Assembly language compiler software written in C Programming language. The system consisted the following sub-modules:
  • Basic Gates in Data Flow modelling
  • Ripple Carry Adder using Structural modelling
  • Arithmetic & Logic Unit (ALU) using Structural Modelling
  • Decoder using Behavioral modelling
  • RAM (Random Access Memory) & Buffers using Dataflow modelling
  • All Sub-Modules Integrated using Structural modelling
  • Assembly language compiler written in C programming language.

projects.title: Wireless Di-Wheel Robot for Navigation on Predefined Routes
projects.description: Designed & Implemented a Computer Controlled Di-Wheeled Robot using PIC16F877 Microcontroller, 27MHz Wireless RC Kit & a pair of geared DC motors each with a power rating of 2 Watts. The routes containing straight lines with bends of either 45 degrees or 90 degrees are drawn using Microsoft Paint software and is stored as a Bitmap image. The Bitmap image is processed using the image processing algorithm written & implemented in <l>MATLAB</l>. The algorithm converts the Bitmap image to a sequence of ASCII formatted bytes containing the information about distances & bend angles according to the lines drawn in the image. The ASCII formated byte sequence generated by the <l>MATLAB</l> algorithm is sent to the Microcontroller through the <l>RS232</l> serial interface of the PC. The algorithm written using the assembly language in the Microcontroller decodes the byte stream received at the <l>RS232</l> interface & through its parallel port interface, controlls the voltage levels at the controll button pins of the RC kit's remote transmitter. The wireless receiver module receives the signals sent by remote transmitter module and decodes them. The in-built driver circuit installed on the Di-Wheeled robot drives the motors attached to its wheels according to the decoded byte codes received. The robot moves in straight lines for specific distance & turns at specific angles in sequence & repeates the steps until the signal transmission is completed which happens when byte stream transmission corresponding to the route completed remotely on the PC.
